messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Scott Stirling [mailto:scottstirling@...]
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: tobemligado <jasbell@...>
[...]
> > My problem is that I need to "trick" the "ConfigManager" into using
> > the three directories in different test scenarios, but I dont want to
> > alter the fact that all objects are created in "ConfigManager's"
> > constructor. Here is what is in the constructor for the
> > singleton "ConfigManager":
> > ----------------------------------------------------
> > String basePath = ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY;
> > setBaseDirectory(basePath);
> > loadAllFilesFound(getBaseDirectory());
[...]
> > How can I switch the CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY value for testing when its
> > in the constructor?
>
> Why can't you just change the value of
> ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY before you call ConfigManager's
> constructor?

Sorry, stupid of me. ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY is a static
final field, right? I missed the coding convention (all upper case
indicating a constant) staring me in the face. So that's why you wouldn't
be able to change the value.

Only thing I can think of right now (different from what J.B. Rainsberger
suggested) is to ask to think why ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY
maybe shouldn't be final. Would it be useful to be able to alter the config
file dir at runtime? Probably not. But it might be nice to let admins
configure it via a system property at start up. If so, you could do the
same thing with your unit test, passing a system property to set the config
file dir from the command line or via System.setProperty(), or even give it
a setter and set it at runtime.

Again, this is an example where AspectJ would be able to help, but that's a
lot of overhead. We need a kit of aspects and examples ready to help with
JUnit testing.

Scott Stirling
